title: How to Make Caramel Apples
original_title: How to Make Caramel Apples
content: hey guys and welcome back today I'm going to show you how to make spooky skeleton caramel apples first you're going to need some white chocolate and the apples of your choice then you're going to need some wooden sticks a piping bag a piping tip cookie sheet and a Silpat or wax paper so for the caramel I'm going to use a can of sweetened condensed milk I'm going to remove the label and put it in a boiling pot of water for three hours make sure that your cans of milk are covered by water the entire cook time next I'm going to push the stick into the Apple making sure that the stick is pushed all the way towards the bottom of the Alpha once your caramel has boiled for three hours you can place it in the refrigerator to cool off for another two hours then you can open up your can and see this beautiful caramel spoon your caramel into a bowl and then put in the microwave for about 45 seconds you'll want your caramel to be a pretty thin consistency for dipping now it's time for dipping dip your apples into the caramel making sure that you have a good thick coat of caramel on each apple if you've missed some spots go ahead and cover those spots up with some extra caramel then place your apples into the refrigerator for about an hour and a half or until your caramel is cool to the touch next melt your chocolate in the microwave for about a minute taking it out every 30 seconds to stir next grab your piping bag that's fitted with a small round circular tip and loaded up once your apples have cooled start by piping on your face you want to round eyes and a triangle nose don't worry about your apples being perfect what makes them cool is that they're all different in unique plus they're pretty messy once you're done with your face you're going to drizzle chocolate about halfway down and it's going to get pretty messy so just have fun with it once i'm done typing i like to take the tip of the bag and blend all the chocolate together so you don't see so many lines and when you're done you can place your apples on a spooky platter or a festive plate and enjoy them at home or share them with friends so I hope you guys enjoyed this video and you got some good Halloween tips please don't forget to Like comment and subscribe if you like what you see happy Halloween thanks for watching

title: How to Make Caramel Apples
original_title: How to Make Caramel Apples
content: back in the real Halloween trick-or-treat days people actually used to make and hand out these instead of this I mean when's the last time you saw that those were the good old days and I think they're pretty much gone partially because people nowadays find it quite a trick to make this traditional fall treat well I've got some good news it's not as much of a trick as you might think hang out for a few minutes because I'm gonna show you how to make this delicious caramel apple the old-fashioned way okay there are basically two ways you can go about making caramel apples number one you can go out and buy some caramels it's the easy way and add two tablespoons of water to every pound of cut caramels and just microwave it until it's smooth and thick or if you're feeling particularly nostalgic you can do number two which is to make this decadent caramel dipping sauce from scratch just like the good old days really come on it's not that difficult and I'm going to show you how plus I had a couple of special finishing touches which make my caramel apples irresistible so let's get right to it here are the ingredients a medium sized saucepan to cook your caramel sauce a candy thermometer that reads to at least 300 degrees Fahrenheit a cookie sheet lightly sprayed with vegetable spray or a silicone non-stick baking mat or wax paper a pastry brush a couple of small bowls and last but not least some sticks for your apples and here's where you can get really creative you can either use one quarter inch wooden dowel rod cut into six inch pieces and sharpened with a pencil sharpener or craft sticks otherwise known as popsicle sticks or you could just cook some cool sticks from your neighbors tree and call it a day to make approximately three cups of caramel dipping sauce or enough to coat about eight to ten medium to small apples you're gonna need one cup of granulated sugar one cup of brown sugar 1/2 cup of light clear corn syrup 1/4 cup of water one and a half cups of heavy whipping cream two teaspoons of pure vanilla extract two tablespoons of salted butter and eight to ten apples your choice but I generally recommend once you prefer eating otherwise I have here some of my favorites Fuji Kiku Honey Crisp and Granny Smith but you can also find a great list of my favorite eating apples in Nino's Apple guide which you can find on our website or in our stores begin by washing drying and inserting 6-inch wooden skewers or craft or popsicle sticks or even twigs into your apples then slightly chill all of them in the refrigerator or in a cool place now avoid chilling them to the point where they sweat when you bring them out to room temperature to make the caramel sauce place the water the corn syrup and both sugars in a medium sized saucepan stir to combine the ingredients well then wash down the sides of the pan with a brush and water then place it on your burner begin cooking the caramel sauce over medium-low heat until it comes to a gentle simmer let it simmer for about five minutes then stir in the cream the vanilla and the butter return the mixture to the burner and turn up the heat to medium and place your thermometer in the pan check it every few minutes until it registers 250 degrees Fahrenheit and then remove the entire sauce from the heat you really don't have to stir it if you don't want to okay we're at two hundred and fifty degrees right now so I'm gonna take my thermometer out and obviously this is too hot to dip apples in right now so we're gonna have to cool it down the best way to do that is I've got over in my sink some cold water and I'm gonna set the pot down into the cold water and just stir it very gently until it starts getting thicker and a little cooler and then eventually I'm gonna transfer it over into a bowl that I can dip my appleson so i'ma head over to think right now I'll join you there two to three inches of cold water is enough to do the trick here just gently stir the sauce until it becomes creamy and fudge-like and that usually takes about a minute okay I've had this cooling in the cold water bath in the sink for a couple of minutes now and it's just about the consistency I want to do my caramel apples so we're gonna put this into a deeper Bowl and that'll allow me to get the Apple right down into the caramel a lot having to roll it around too much you can see how beautifully thick this caramel sauce is so we'll just get it all in there and now what I'm gonna do is bring up my apples and start dipping let's check our apples they've been now chillin for about 15-20 minutes they're just nice and cool but they're not to refrigerate it if you know what I'm talking about they're not too cold I have my sauce that we just brought off of the range put on our little water bath in there and got nice and cool and so you're just gonna make sure they're not sweating which they are not and we're gonna dip this down almost to the stem roll it around a little bit like this check that out now it takes quite a while for the caramel sauce to run completely off so what I like to do is when I start getting a nice gathering of sauce on the bottom I wipe the bottom just like this and then turn it upside down and just kind of rotate it a bit and that'll allow the caramel sauce to evenly coat the outside of the apple at that point in time we're gonna set it down and pick up another one plunge it all the way into the sauce so maybe you can still see a little bit of the Apple on top just like this and this one while it's still soft I'm going to add one of my ingredients that I love adding and that's smoked sea salt and I have some right here it's called Falk salt we sell it at Nino's so what I'll do here just wipe this off and then right around the top just the top rim only I like to put this smoked salt and it makes your Apple taste so smoky and salty around that caramel sweetness it's a little bit like us some mores in the fall just a wonderful taste get the extra caramel sauce off and go on to my next Apple now I have one more secret that I add to my caramel apples and that's chocolate I'm gonna do that a second okay here's step two of my wickedly delicious caramel apples I did one with smoked salt and I did one without we're gonna finish these both the same way and that's with chocolate now you can buy chocolate dip which we have at Nino's it's called the Dulce fruit de and you can melt this right in this cup and it works great or you can take three ounces of chocolate morsels and add one tablespoon of vegetable oil I melt that microwave oven it'll work the same way so I have right here my fruit date Dolce and I'm going to dip it about a third of the way in chocolate so I now have the smoked sea salt I have the caramel and I have the chocolate and this hardens pretty quickly as you can see and just set it down just like that and get my other one here and dip it to right about halfway up maybe and it doesn't take long to to harden at all mmm just swipe the bottom like that and we're done so whether you like smoked salt on yours and chocolate or just caramel and chocolate just plain caramel or any other types of toppings you can imagine from nuts to cookies and ground candies of all different kinds you've got to try these caramel apples out this fall they're delicious now as I mentioned there are loads of other top things you can decorate your caramel apples with just keep in mind that you want to sprinkle or or roll them onto your caramel apples just after you dip them and before the caramel sets most important have fun hey let me know how your caramel apples turned out what apples did you use what toppings did you try I'm Pete Lauren director of culinary development at Nino's if you enjoyed this clip and would like to see others just like it check out Nino's very own youtube channel right on the home page of our website at wwlp.com and while you're there be sure to like us on facebook or send me a tweet at Nino's chef Pete

title: How to Make Caramel Apples
original_title: How To Make Caramel Apples! (Recipe)
content: hey guys how to make caramel apples it's that time of year again and I so look forward to caramel apples this is what you're going to need you're going to need some individually wrapped caramels you can get them at any store even at the dollar store you're also going to need some apples I use smaller apples any kind will do anything that you like you're also going to need candies any kind of candies I have candy ghosts and bats crushed peanuts Halloween sprinkles caramel crunchy bits white mini chocolate chips a little bit of milk and I use different colors of chocolate you can use in any kind of chocolate chocolate chips you can use candy melts I use candy melts because they come in really great colors but you can use anything you like line a cookie sheet with wax paper and generously cover it with butter why should dry your apples thoroughly now you're going to need popsicle sticks or kick pop sticks or lollipop sticks and you want to insert them at the core all the way down but make sure that it doesn't come out on the other side in a heavy-bottomed pot put all your car mills in put your milk in and I always start it out on low when the car will start to melt a bit I put it on a medium low and it should be very very smooth when you're finished no more bumps or lumps in it but never walk away from this because it can scorch really easily here comes the fun part all you have to do is get your Apple and tilt your pot and roll the apple in the caramel you can roll it half way up or all the way up and what I do is usually brush the bottom of the apple on the pot just ever so lightly because it will pool quite a bit on the bottom if you don't do that so just drag it along the pot and take the excess off then you want to put on your candies or your nuts if you have very heavy candy the car milk can tend to slip that's why I try to stick with very light candies and nuts I know a lot of people do put larger things on the caramel apple but the caramels sometimes sometimes slips so the lighter your candies are the more successful it will be to keep them higher up on your Apple getting as much wax off your apples when you're washing and drying them also helps with this and when you're done putting the candy on just put it on your cookie sheet you can also use melted chocolate I use black and orange all I did was melt it really quickly put it in homemade parchment bag and I just drizzle it along the candy apple you can get so many great colors this time of year and it's always a lot of fun to do I hope you give this a go happy Halloween everybody till next time hey dough

title: How to Make Caramel Apples
original_title: How to make Caramel Apples | 3 quick and easy ways
content: hi guys how are you today I'm going to be sharing with you not really a recipe but how I make care of my apples let's begin I'm going to be sharing with you three easy ways to make this for adults for kids or people who don't like eating so much sweets most apples have wax and that is not good when dipping the apples in the caramel because it will slip off so to get rid of it I just took some warm water and I place the apples inside and let it soak for about fifteen to twenty minutes while the apples were soaking I chopped up some Oreos and peanuts I also use shredded coconut some M&Ms feel free to use whatever you have available at home be creative once I was finished chopping everything up I set that aside I took out a saucepan out of the caramel and two tablespoons of water and I stood by the stove and I just continued mixing it don't leave the stove or you will accidentally burn the caramel it doesn't take long to completely melt the caramel probably about two minutes once it's all melted I took my apple which already had the stick inserted and I dipped it in the caramel and just slowly turned it around till I coated almost the whole apple immediately transfer it into the nuts or whatever you are using to cover the caramel apple notice how it just falls off it's because I waited a little bit too long to add the nuts so basically what I did was I just pressed it in now another way to make these caramel apples is to slice the apples into wedges and stick either popsicle stick for me I just use a cake pop stick and just dip into the caramel and coat it now if your caramel hardens just place it back onto the stove for about ten to fifteen seconds and you should be able to dip the apples easily so the third way to make these caramel apples was I stuck three cake pop sticks into the apples then I sliced them then dipped them in the caramel for this Apple I decided to use coconut and you can see me really like pressing in it's because I waited again too long literally it takes about five seconds for it to harden so quickly cover it with whatever ingredient you want to use and that's it guys super easy very fun to make and all ages could eat these so I'll guys let me know in the comments how you make your caramel apples what ingredients to use thank you guys so much for watching and I will see you on my next upload bye guys

title: How to Make Caramel Apples
original_title: How to Make Caramel Apples | Candy Making
content: so today I'm making some caramel apples so you can see I'm starting with these really cute red and green apple speaking use any kind that you can find in the market I especially love this little mini ones so great for parties but all I'm going to do is I have these really fun kind of straws and I'm gonna use these as my lollipop sticks just kind of press it right into your Apple be which is basically just sugar a little bit of water a little corn syrup and heavy cream and you can see it's nice and thick and ready to dip and I'm just going to take my apple and dip it right into my caramel sauce I don't like to cover too much of the Apple but I do like to give it a nice bottom so I'm just going to kind of let any excess drip right off of it now let's keep this one plain and then we'll do a couple with some fun toppings but just kind of get the little excess off the bottom and then right on to I like to use a Silpat which is a non-stick baking nut but you can definitely use a piece of parchment paper or anything that you have a keep your surface clean that's always a good idea with caramel so again just kind of dip right in there yeah so now we're gonna go into some fun toppings so you have a choice if you really use anything that you like but I have some sprinkles so I'm just gonna go ahead and while my caramel is still nice and warm just kind of rock into my title: How to Make Caramel Apples

content: here's a grownup version of caramel apples that will please the child in all of us combined cardamom with ground pistachios on a small plate insert a stick halfway into each Apple we used lady apples as they're in season but crab apples are also great when they're available place a sheet of parchment paper on top of a cookie sheet dip Athens mini filo shells into melted chocolate almost covering the outside of the shell then dip the bottom half into the nut mixture place the dip shells on the parchment paper now dip the apples into melted caramel let the excess caramel drip off then drizzle melted chocolate over the caramel and sprinkle a few nuts over the chocolate for a layered look carefully place each caramel apple into a mini phyllo shell repeat the process until each shell is filled refrigerate for 15 minutes or until the caramel and chocolate are hardened Athens mini filo shells available in your grocers freezer

content: caramel is a really versatile building block for dozens of different desserts making your own cromwell's a really simple process but there are a few pitfalls to watch out for one is the criminalization of the sugar which can cause the mixture to solidify and the second is either under cooking or over cooking your caramel in this video I'll show you how to make a basic caramel that's perfectly cooked as well as how to transform it into a delicious and easy caramel sauce now for my setup I have a pastry brush with some water and a 2 quart saucepan for the caramel I'm going to start with 1 cup of sugar a quarter cup of water and a quarter teaspoon of lemon juice this is going to help prevent the caramel from crystallizing and seizing up as it cooks so the first thing I'm do is just use my pastry brush and just wipe down the sides of the pan getting any little sugar crystals that are on the side of the pan you want to wash those down ok that looks good now I'm going to place this over medium-high heat and bring it up to a boil now you don't want to stir your caramel as it cooks that can cause crystallization so you just want to occasionally swirl the pan just like this now this method is called a wet caramel because we're adding the water there's also a method called a dry caramel where you don't add any water it cooks a little bit faster but you run the risk of scorching your sugar so the water is going to help to prevent that so basically we're just letting that water cook off and then the sugar is going to start to caramelize ok so now that my mixture has come to a boil I'm going to let it continue cooking until it starts to get a little color and I'll go back in there with my wet pastry brush and just continue to wash down the sides every now and then and again you don't want to stir but you can give the pan a little swirl okay so it's just starting to change color a little bit around the edges and in a few spots so at this point you just want to give the pan a little swirl to start to even out the color and this is the time when you really want to watch your caramel because if you step away it can go from undercooked to burnt really quickly so just keep an eye on it and keep swirling the pan now you can test your caramel by playing a little drop on a white plate so I'll show you what it looks like at this point so this as you can see is really light this is going to have very little of that bittersweet caramel flavor that we're looking for just a few seconds later and it's a little bit darker this is a light caramel again we don't really use caramel at this stage it's not going to have the complexity that we're looking for the darker caramel goes the more complexity it's going to have now we have a medium amber this is what you'll use for caramel sauce or a lot of different recipes that we have on our website and watch closely and pay attention because in just a few seconds we're going to have a dark amber and here we have a dark amber now this is what you would use for creme caramel or anywhere where you want a really assertive strong caramel flavor now when you're at the point you want you want to remove your pan from the heat and you want to use your caramel right away because it hardens up rather quickly one of the easiest things to do with your batch of caramel is to make a caramel sauce so I've got a new batch that I've started and it's at the medium amber stage so at this point I'm going to pull it off the heat and add 3/4 of cup of heavy cream now you want to stand back because it will splatter a little bit and come is very hot and I'm going to put it back on the heat and you can stir it at this point with the wooden spoon and you'll notice that some of it starts to seize up but as it melts it'll get nice and smooth now to finish the caramel I'm going to add two tablespoons of butter I'm just going to add it slowly I've cut it up into small pieces and I'll add just a few at a time and then stir it in to melt beautiful once the butter is all melted the last thing to add is a teaspoon of vanilla extract mmm this smells like heaven this is perfect for drizzling over ice cream over fruit or basically in any kind of chocolate dessert

title: How to Make Caramel Apples
original_title: Homemade Caramel Apples
content: if you went the perfect Halloween treat there is nothing like a caramel apple these caramel apples aren't just a regular caramel apple they first your dipped in the perfect consistency of caramel with that great amber color with that sweet and bitter flavor then once they're a little bit cooled they are drizzled with chocolate and of course have a few extra toppings with some toasted pecans and candy toffee pieces these are over-the-top and a perfect not at all spooky tree make these perfect caramel apples all coming up on today's wipeout I know you can't really hand out homemade treats when trick-or-treaters come a knocking on your door but if you happen to know the people or you have nieces and a nephew like I do or just family and friends or if you're having a party caramel apples are a great thing to have I don't know why but there is just something that seems so festive for Halloween about a caramel apple I'm gonna admit I don't necessarily go over-the-top for Halloween I have a few simple decorations I mostly love fall but I do collect the vintage jack-o'-lantern Halloween decorations because well you know everything vintage but I love to do anything festive and so to make a special treat for the holiday is always on my mind caramel apples can sometimes be a little tricky it sounds easy you just make a caramel you dip it but when I was making these for you guys I realized to get the perfect caramel it's not that easy you don't want one too thin so it just all comes off and if it's too thick it doesn't really dip in easily and you kind of have to spread it and that's not fun either so you want the perfect consistency caramel and this is exactly what you're gonna get to start you just want to take a four quart kettle and put in some sugar and a little bit of water set that on the stove over medium heat to slowly let it come up to a boil while that's happening you can get ready everything that's going to go on these caramel apples first obviously the apples I like to pick kind of medium to smaller apples because you're adding so much to them and they can be kind of awkward to eat so you want to pick a smaller Apple to begin with because those jumbo size apples which by the way kind of freak me out in the grocery store they're seriously like Frankenstein so start with a smaller Apple and if you know me you know I always pick a Honey Crisp you just want to put a handle in these apples I like to use kind of a sturdy stick I get these at cake decorating stores they're actually used to kind of lift cakes up if you need to and support them but if you cut them in half they're a perfect stick for these otherwise you could just use a popsicle stick just stick them right in the center until it feels like it has a good hold in there and then set them aside for the toppings I'm gonna use some toasted pecans because who doesn't love a toasted pecan okay I know some of you a throw like I don't you can totally leave them out if you don't want to all this is customizable just chop them up into small pieces and then set them aside [Music] I'm also using some candy coated toffee bits you can find these and they're ready to go section in the baking aisle they're just in a bag it is so simple and then I'm gonna also melt some dark chocolate just to put on top too and just kind of drizzle it over them I choose dark chocolate because the caramel is so sweet that it kind of has a nice bitterness against it and really balances it out while your water and sugar is boiling you want to just swirl the pan you don't want to stir it too much or that could really cost some crystallization once all that sugar is dissolved and the water starts evaporating off you're gonna start getting a little bit of color first it'll be very faint just a light light light brown color keep swirling the pan and eventually you're gonna notice a darker amber color I like to take mine fairly dark definitely over 300 degrees I've got about 310 degrees you do not have to temperature this if you don't want to I just like to know where I'm at take it to whatever color you like for me it's always gonna be a little darker once it's at the right color just pull that off the heat you don't want to add your cream while it's on beat slowly add in your room temperature cream if you add in really cold cream that's gonna really sputter and could almost boil over so just slowly add a few tablespoons at a time and stir it in until it's really combined once all your cream is in it should be a really smooth mixture if it's not don't fret just put it over a very low heat your burner is probably still gonna be hot enough without it even on and just keep stirring it until it's smooth [Music] once it's smooth you can just remove it from the heat completely and add in some salt because you know I need some of that salt with all this sweet caramel and then a little bit of vanilla the vanilla just really amps up the flavor and I always love vanilla stir that in and then let it cool once it's cooled for about five or ten minutes I would just pour it into a glass measuring cup this is gonna help it cool down quicker you want this to be almost fully at room temperature so I like to set mine in the fridge for about 30 minutes stirring every 10 minutes and seeing how quickly it's gonna solidify when it's at the right consistency you can start dipping your apples dipping the apples is the fun part just take your measuring cup put an apple over the top dip it in if it's solidified a little bit too much you could heat it in the microwave slightly to thin it down or just take a spatula and spoon it over slowly let it fall down that's gonna give it a smooth coating and then just set it right on top of a parchment lined baking sheet and I like to make sure that baking sheet was in the freezer for about 20 minutes before I do this that's just gonna make sure once you set it on that baking sheet that that caramel is gonna set right away you're still gonna get some that drips off and pools on the bottom no problem that's normal that will give you a smooth finish still when all your apples are dipped you can just finish with the chocolate melt your chocolate in the microwave about thirty to forty second increments stirring between until it's completely smooth I just like to use these melting chips they're really quick just drizzle on the chocolate on top of that caramel and then put them on a clean piece of parchment on top of a baking sheet this way you're not gonna put them back into all that pooled caramel on the other sheet and when you're putting on your nuts and your toffee I like to finish by dipping them back in the nuts to make sure there is a good base for them to sit on that way they are not just gonna get stuck to the parchment like when they were dripping off they're gonna have a really great base layer on them and so there will come right off it's almost like a nonstick layer it's the perfect thing [Music] after you get all of your toppings whatever customized toppings that you want to put on it just set them on the baking sheet and they are ready to go at this point you can put them in the fridge for up to about one day or you could just eat them right away I like to put them in the fridge for a little bit just to make sure they really hardened up that chocolates hard the caramel set but then just enjoy them we're gonna be honest they can be kind of hard to bite out of so don't feel bad if you get a knife out and just cut them up because they're a little bit more enjoyable this is the perfect Halloween treat and even if it's not Halloween you can enjoy these all fall along I love to make these for my family members my nieces and my nephew and just see the joy on their faces and really see the joy on my face if you agree make sure to like share subscribe for the recipe go to the description box until next time have a happy Halloween [Music] you [Music]

content: hello and welcome to soul food cooking today I'll be making caramel apples you will need organic Gala apples 211 ounce packages of caramel 2 tablespoons of milk 1 8 ounce package of heath toffee bits and chopsticks the toffee bits I'm using do not contain peanuts so please be sure to check your label line a cookie sheet with parchment paper then lightly spray it with cooking oil remove the stems from the apple thoroughly wash and dry them then place the chopsticks through the center of the Apple adds a milk to the caramel then melt the caramel in a double boiler stirring frequently dip the apples in the caramel turning to make sure that each side is coated allow the excess caramel to run off the apples before placing them on the cookie sheet [Music] now cover the apples with the toffee making sure they're well coated transfer the apples to the refrigerator and allow them to sit for 15 minutes after 15 minutes your apples are now ready to serve thanks for watching and don't forget to subscribe to soul food cooking [Music] so cookie [Music]

tablespoons of water and a double boiler I'll show you what I use cuz I myself don't have a double boiler so we're going to start out by peeling our apples so I'm gonna go ahead and take the bigger side of the melon baller and I'm going to go ahead and cut out little circles or little bowls from apples I was able to get around five or six of these pieces per Apple and my apples were about medium sized so I'm going to take my lollipop sticks I'm gonna stick those right into the center of those pieces so if you have a double boiler to melt the caramel then use that if you don't then what you need is a little pot like a little saucepan like this and a smaller saucepan that will fit nice and snug inside the bigger one I'm going to turn the heat on to a medium to high heat and I'm gonna fill up my bigger saucepan with water making sure that the water does not touch the smaller saucepan when I put it inside so when I lift it up you'll be able to see that no water is dripping because the water doesn't touch if it does touch a little bit then that's okay but usually they recommend for it not to touch so now I'm going to leave the water to boil and while it's boiling we are gonna unwrap the caramels the ones that I caught are individually wrapped but that's totally okay I'm just gonna unwrap all of them and I'm gonna put them into the smaller saucepans I'm going to go ahead and then title: How to Make Caramel Apples
original_title: Caramel Apple Recipe
content: caramel or caramel no matter how you say it we love you gooey caramel on top of our favorite fall trees caramel apples we've got a few tips to help you make this at home first let's prepare our apples I'm using tart apples but use whatever variety you prefer remove the stems from the apples and insert a skewer into the stem end then set the apples on a buttered baking sheet next we'll make our caramel in a saucepan combine 1 14 ounce package of vanilla caramels add 2 tablespoons of whipping cream cook and stir this mixture over medium low until completely melted if the mixture becomes too thick reheat a few minutes to desired consistency working quickly dip each Apple in the caramel mixture turning to coat if you want to add toppings now's the time try chopped nuts crushed pretzels or chocolate chips have fun and experiment with different flavors let your apples stand until set and that's how you make this easy recipe for caramel apples right at home happy cooking

title: How to Make Caramel Apples
original_title: How It's Made: Caramel Apples
content: [Music] hi it's Gary den school again here at tweetsie fudge works and today we're going to be making a crowd-pleaser our world-famous caramel apples caramel apples are something that have been around for a long time I like to use a tart apple like a wine sap or something like that to contrast a little bit with the sweet caramel today we're going to be using granny smith apples one of my favorite hours the first thing we do is obviously inspect all the apples whatever Apple you buy is coated has been coated with some sort of wax to make the apple shine we've got to get rid of that wax or the caramel won't stick to so each apple is washed then it's and dried after the apples have dried we go over the apples can we pull the stems off all the actives and the reason that we do that is because the next step is putting the sticks in the Apple and so you remove the stem so that when you set the Apple down it will sit flat then we go through the caramel preparation caramel is basically just sugar and milk it's boiled together and that's called the Maillard reaction the caramelization after we have that then we dip the apples in the caramel and we spin the apple to remove the excess caramel and then we set the apples down on sugar the reason that we use sugar is that it keeps the bottom of the apple dry that way the caramel the sticky caramel doesn't stick to the trade and we're going to put them after that they sit for about 20 or 30 minutes for the caramel to cool and and we move them to a clean tray and move them into our display case then they're ready to sell thanks for watching and please come back and watch more tips from the much work spirit sweet seek and remember we have lots of free samples so please come to [Music]

title: How to Make Caramel Apples
original_title: How To Make Caramels from Scratch
content: hey you guys welcome to my channel today I'm going to show you how to make these delicious chewy caramel candies from scratch using really simple ingredients this is an old-fashioned recipe that I know you're really going to love and they're way better than the ones you buy in a store it's a pretty easy recipe but there are a couple of steps involved so let's get started in a small saucepan measuring two cups of 35% cream now if you take your empty cream cartons and heat them gently for a few seconds on each side like this the rest of the cream will come out now heat this to a lukewarm and set it aside now in a medium saucepan measure out two cups of sugar and one cup of corn syrup don't forget to oil that measuring cup first though now over medium heat stir this constantly until all the sugar dissolves and the mixture comes to a boil but once it starts boiling stop stirring it this is when you're going to want to clip on a candy thermometer and you're going to want to cook the mixture to 250 degrees Fahrenheit or firm ball stage now if you don't have a candy thermometer just take a little bit of the mixture and drop it into some really cold water if it forms a firm ball like this it's done that'll take about five minutes now you're going to want to start slowly adding that lukewarm cream bit by bit so the mixture never stops boiling don't worry if it boils like crazy at first just keep adding it until all the cream is gone and then you have to let it cook until it reaches 250 degrees again this could take up to 30 minutes or even longer and even though the candy thermometer is reliable the cold water test is the best way to be sure you're there now you'll want to start adding in half a cup of cubed butter the same way you add it in the cream slowly bit by bit so the mixture never stops oiling like this keep doing that until all the butters used up and then let it cook for another two minutes or so or until it reaches firm ball stage again remember to check with that cold water test if you don't have a candy thermometer then you can take it off the heat remove the candy thermometer and now you'll want to stir in one teaspoon of vanilla extract if you were using unsalted butter now you'll want to add in one teaspoon of salt I was using salted butter so I'm not going to bother now generously oil an 8 or 9 inch square pan and pour your caramel mixture into it scrape out as much of it as you can and now you have to let this sit for a few hours to set up then it's going to look like this now you can cut your caramels and as many squares as you want I cut mine into 64 if you cook the caramel to a proper firm ball stage your candies are going to have just the right texture now you're going to have to individually wrap each candy or they're going to stick together when you store them you can just use wax paper or you can use fancy gold wrappers like this so there you have it I hope you try this recipe soon and don't forget to subscribe to my channel for more awesome recipes and painting fun have a good day guys bye

content: hey everyone it's James from fun foods and today I'm going to show you how to make these delicious chocolate covered caramel apples with sea salt now these are delicious they're beautiful you'll see how lovely they are you can use dark chocolate milk chocolate whatever you desire you can even use white chocolate if you wish now whatever way you do this you're going to love it they taste amazing so follow along and I'll show you step by step how to make these start by rinsing off your apples with some cold water be sure to dry the Apple as well so if you haven't skimmed the apples now will be a good time to do so just pop them off insert a stick at least halfway through the apples peel 111 ounce package of caramels and place in a microwave-safe bowl add 2 tablespoons of water and melt stir every 30 seconds when your caramels are melted dip your apples in it and cover it completely place on a greased wax paper surface let cool in the refrigerator for about 30 to 40 minutes melt some chocolate and dip your caramel apples in the chocolate leave the top portion of the caramel exposed place on a new wax paper tray and sprinkle a little sea salt on now a few more pieces of caramel and add a small amount to the top of the Apple this isn't a must but it does enhance the look keep refrigerated until about 15 minutes before ready to serve well thanks everyone for watching to see how to make these chocolate-covered caramel apples with sea salt I hope you enjoyed this video and if you did please hit that like button below also subscribe to my channel if you aren't already and you'll see new videos every Sunday at 2 o'clock and check out some videos I have off to the side that you may enjoy you also see that little eye button popping up throughout the thing and that is the new YouTube cards and their suggested videos along the way throughout my video today and videos that I think you may be interested in so you can give those a little - content: [Music] I'm Michelle and welcome to the Kraft kitchens if you like caramel apples during Halloween I have two great treats for your little ghosts and goblins ultimate caramel apples and caramel apple nachos so to start let's make the caramel apples so I have 5 really nice-looking apples here and I'm going to add to the center wooden pop sticks so just remove the stem and insert the Pops stick inside just push it right down now the trick to remember is that you have to really wash your apples really well you want to remove any wax that might be left on the Apple and then you want to make sure that they're really dry because caramel won't stick to a wet apple melting craft caramels is really easy so I'm going to give you a couple of quick tricks first to open a caramels squeeze them pinch them really hard in the center and then the wrapping will open right up the other option you can do is you can put them on a tray pop them in the freezer for about 15 minutes and the wrapping will come off the other one is get your kids to do it so now what you're going to do is take the 1 package and put it into a microwavable bowl and I'm going to add to it 2 tablespoons of water it'll pop this in the microwave and cook it on high power for 3 minutes I'll take it out after one and a half minutes stir it put it back in finish the time and then when I take it back out I'll stir it again to make sure the caramels are completely melted you can also do this on top of the stove in a saucepan over low heat and make sure you continuously stir to make sure the caramels are melting perfectly now for the fun part dipping the apples so I have my melted caramels here my apples I'm going to insert the Apple into the warm caramel moving it around like so making sure that the Apple is evenly covered and then you pull it out doesn't that look great now I take a little a knife or spatula and you just wipe the excess off in the bottom and I'm going to place this on top of a baking sheet that I've lined with wax paper or parchment that I've really well buttered and that's the key you have to remember to butter the wax paper because that will prevent your apples from sticking to the paper as they set now this is a great time to that you can decorate the caramel apples if you wish you can top them with some chopped peanuts or with some baker's semi-sweet or white chocolate melted drizzle the chocolate on or even some crushed Oreos now we're going to make our caramel apple nachos so what I've done ahead of time is melted 18 Kraft caramels in two teaspoons of water and i microwave them on high for one and a half minutes and I took it out every 30 seconds and I stirred the caramels to make sure that they were melting nicely so that's all done I've also sliced two apples and I've arranged them nicely on this plate and just overlapping you can do it in a circle as well if you want so I'm going to top the apples with the melted caramels just drizzle back and forth all over just like you would your regular nachos and then for the topping I'm going to top with one cup jet puff miniature marshmallows and just price them all around - crushed Oreo cookies and a quarter cup chopped dry roasted peanuts and there you have it these caramel apple trees are so easy and they're fun to make at your next Halloween party you're going to be a hit for more great recipes and videos visit us at craft canada.com [Music] you

title: How to Make Caramel Apples
original_title: How To Make Caramel Candy
content: hi I'm Anthony and I'm going to show you how to make caramel candies and first step is just to get your ingredients ready your first ingredient is sugar 1 cup of white granulated sugar that's seven and a half ounces ingredient number two isn't quite so obvious it's a quarter cup of light corn syrup you're probably asking well why corn syrup let's find out this is sucrose take a fable sugar it's made up of a bunch of carbons and some oxygens and some hydrogen's to fill the clutch and as you probably already know sucrose has a tendency to form crystals and you can heat those crystals up or dissolve them in water and it becomes a liquid but as soon as it dries out or cools down it's going to become a crystal again and if you're making candy with sugar sucrose then that's going to lead to a sort of grainy sandy texture in your candy you don't want that especially in caramels so one method to prevent the crystallization of sucrose once it's in a liquid form is to introduce some sort of acid like lemon juice or cream of tartar what that does is split sucrose down the middle into glucose and fructose which won't crystallize unfortunately since assets tastes a little sour you can bite into a lemon if you want to test that your candy is not going to be a sweet and you probably want your candy to be sweet so another solution to prevent sucrose from crystallizing is to introduce something else that prevents the sucrose molecules from touching each other and actually forming crystals sort of like creating a barrier around the molecules so that they don't form crystals with one enough and that's where the corn syrup comes in and i'll demonstrate let's suppose these three-dimensional blogs are sucrose molecules when you push them together in one space they have this tendency to form a crystal a sugar crystal but you can tear them apart by melting them with heat or dissolving them and add something like say warm syrup then pushing them together the corn syrup interferes with these molecules ability to recrystallize and so you don't get this grainy texture as if you are biting into a sugar cube you get a smoother texture as if this were still a liquid and that's what you want for a caramel and nice thing about corn syrup is that it's mostly glucose anyway so it'll add sweetness to your candy and also be completely flavorless next ingredient is four tablespoons of butter that's half a stick and the fat will serve a similar purpose as the corn syrup the salt will accent the sweetness and this is salted butter so that's alright but if you're using unsalted butter you're going to want to add about a quarter teaspoon of this stuff and your last big ingredient is going to be one cup of heavy cream again that's more fat to prevent recrystallization of the sugar plus the proteins in the cream will react with the sugar and create that dark brown caramel color that is characteristic of caramel plus it's pretty tasty vanilla extract is an optional ingredient but it adds a nice start off with a glass pan about two quarts be the size you want and line it with either parchment paper wax paper or aluminum foil any of those will work but if you use aluminum foil you're probably going to want to grease the aluminum foil once it's in the pan just to guarantee that your candy won't stick to it sometimes I have problems with aluminum foil sometimes I don't so with ingredients on hand grab yourself a fairly large size cooking pot roberson mixing and then start tossing in your ingredients one after the other but the only thing I'd hold off on is the vanilla is if you cook it too long then you'll cook the flavor away and then though what's appointing and adding it at that point so remember save with vanilla to the end and in the corn syrup turn the heat on to about medium so it looks like my butter is about melting so now I'm going to add this to the pot this is a candy thermometer and it's absolutely vital for this process and I'll tell you why so you may or may not have realized it but the cream and butter that you have any mixture have moisture do they have water in them and water changes it stayed at 212 degrees it becomes steam it evaporates so liquid water itself will not get above 212 degrees because it turns with something else at that one but your candy in the mixture is actually going to want to get much hotter the sugar will get way hotter than 212 but the water in it because it has this 212 cap is actually going to cool down the whole mixture so as water evaporates the less water you have the less cooling you have and the less cooling you have the hotter your candy can actually get and it turns out when your candy is about 250 degrees maybe a little bit lower than that then enough water has evaporated and title: How to Make Caramel Apples
original_title: How to Make Caramel Apples on a Stick : Chocolate Dreams
content: hi I'm Kevin Raye from Peter brick chocolatier and today we're going to teach you how to make caramel apples on a stick I'm going to start off with an ice granny smith apple we recommend these because they have a nice tartness that goes well with the caramel we're going to take the stem off just simply by holding it and twisting the Apple and then we want to wash the Apple well we're going to rub it with a towel we don't want to add water to the Apple at this point because that's going to make the caramel hard to stick so we're just going to rub the wax off the Apple now we got a nice shiny apple and we're going to take a wooden dowel or a paper apple stick and you're going to hold it and take it down straight to the core of the Apple you want to be careful not to go through the bottom and then when you set it up that your Apple sits upright next we're going to start off with a very high quality caramel and you want to make sure you have enough in your dish so you can completely dip the Apple easily so we're going to get in the microwave and start melting it down so we can cut our apples and we're going to start off with about five minutes I'm going to stir in between to make sure the caramel mixes and doesn't burn on the sides so about every two minutes all right we've got our caramel out of the microwave and as you can see it's a nice thick consistency but still liquidy enough to work with so we're going to take our apple and we're going to press it down into the caramel and go ahead and ring it all the way to the edge of the top of the stick pull it out this beautiful caramel starts running off and I like to use a knife just to kind of turn it and scrape the bottom so you end up with too much extra caramel now our caramel apple is ready we're going to put in the refrigerator to cool and you're ready to eat enjoy

content: it's tutorial Tuesday and I don't know about you but what's Halloween without caramel apples if you love caramel apples as much as I do stay tuned for the tutorial so here is everything that hold our apples on but you can also use lollipop sticks or even popsicle sticks if you'd like chopped peanuts and this is going to be toppings for our caramel apples a few candy melts and this is also going to be toppings for our caramel apples and you don't have to use the peanuts for the candy melts these are optional so the first thing you're going to do which I've already done off camera is make sure you wash your apples and you want to make sure that you watch them really well under some warm water so that you can get all the wax off and once they're all wash do you want to make sure that you dry them all the way completely because if they're wet or if they do have a little bit of wax the caramel won't stick so after you've done that we're going to take our skewer and each apple has a little center hole we're just going to poke the skewer right through the center and you might need an adult to help you do this part see just like that and your Apple will sit nicely on top of microwave for about a minute and a half then we're going to stir it take it out and stir it and then put it back in for another minute and a half take it out stir it and it should be all melted ok so our caramel is all melted and it's time to dip our apples and this is the time that you're going to put all your toppings on once they're dipped once the caramel is still sticky before it sets is when you're going to add your toppings so here we go so you take your Apple you put it upside down you dunk it in the caramel and you just give it a nice twist to coat your Apple just like that and you let some of the excess just drip right off of it so this first Apple we're just going to leave it just basic just the basic caramel apple and then we're going to place it on our wax paper and the trick so that your Apple does not stick to your wax paper is make sure that you put a little bit of butter or maybe vegetable spray on your wax paper so it doesn't stick so then after we do that we just place just like this swirl it around then we're going to let the excess drip off wait and then we're going to put it down to set the rest so I will be back to show you how I do my drizzle once they're all set I'm back and my candy apples are pretty much set but I just wanted to come back to show you how I do the drizzle so the bag of candy melts that I had I just put them in some hot water and just waited for them to melt so all I'm going to do is take my scissors and just clip off the end right there and just snip off the end like that van I'm going to take my apple like so take my drizzle in this hand sorry this is kind of awkward when you're recording it and I'm just going to squeeze it all the way to the end and then just drizzle it on just like that it's been sitting for a while so it's not as liquidy as I'd like it but you guys get the point right I hope so but pretty much you just do that and do whatever kind of design that you like and there you have it folks my caramel apples we have one caramel with some chocolate drizzle one regular caramel and one with some peanuts I hope this helped you guys thanks for watching and I'll see you guys next time bye

content: welcome to my channel today I'm going to show you how to make a caramel macchiato on my Breville barista Express okay so right here I'm I have my machine on and I'm taking my vanilla syrup and I'm gonna pour it into my coffee cup it's about two tablespoons but I I it and you can choose however much you want to put in and now I'm gonna go ahead and start steaming my milk I like to steam my wand for a second before steaming my milk and as you can see when I'm steaming it I like to see a rotation of the milk basically counterclockwise seeing the milk swirl counterclockwise and you're gonna keep steaming it until it hits about a hundred and sixty degrees on this joke that I have in my hands it actually has a temperature gauge on it so I like to keep an eye on that instead of using a thermometer if you don't have either you can always use your hand so it gets way too hot to hold you can just that's when you'll want to turn off your steamer and I like to tap it and swirl it around now you'll see me pouring the milk in and what makes it a macchiato is you put the espresso on top of this team to milk here you'll see that I'm doing a double shot from my Bravo barista Express so you'll want to pour your espresso over the milk so that's one shot and here's my second shot and what makes it a caramel macchiato is that you top it with caramel sauce on top and what I like to do is I like to put a ring of caramel sauce around and then horizontally put caramel sauce and then vertically crisscross and then there you have a caramel macchiato thanks for watching make sure to subscribe below and I will see you in my next video

original_title: How to make Salted Caramel
content: today I'm making salted caramel for this you'll need a heavy-based saucepan with some high sides just to be safe as the caramel will bubble up later castor sugar unsalted butter double cream and sea salt flakes the quantities for the ingredients will be listed in the description box below to start on a medium heat pour in your sugar and continually stir make sure you have all of your ingredients ready as once the sugar has melted it will be a very quick process at first it will feel like nothing is happening but give it a minute and the sugar will start to form clumps make sure you use a spatula that is heat proof as you don't want it to melt as soon as the sugar has completely melted into a lovely amber color and there is no more sugar lumps add your butter and continue stirring until the butter has melted but be careful as it will bubble up and be very hot feel free to lower the temperature if it gets too hot as we don't want to burn the caramel gradually add your double cream and stir until it is all combined and had a little boil take it off the heat and stir in your sea salt flakes leave it on the side to cool as it will be very hot while your caramel is cooling sterilize your jars so you can keep the caramel for longer by washing them in very hot water and popping them in the oven for 10 minutes at 120 degrees fan but other temperatures they'll be listed here pour your caramel into your sterilized jars and leave on the side to cool at room temperature store your caramel in the fridge until needed you can enjoy this caramel in many different ways by eating it with shortbreads drizzling it over ice cream or just eating out of the jar if you eat it straight from the fridge it's a lovely chewy consistency if you let it come to room temperature it's a lot softer and malleable and I also like to melt some in the microwave to drizzle over ice cream and hot chocolate to clean your pan pop it back onto the heat with some washing-up liquid and some water and it will come right off for more video subscribe to my channel if you enjoyed the video give it a thumbs up and feel free to leave any requests in the comment box below

content: hi i'm chef mark with learn2cook.com today we'll be making a caramel dip for apples or pears or fruit pretzels whatever you want to dip into the caramel sauce it's great to serve also to pour over ice cream so we'll be making uh caramel sauce you'll need eight ounces of sugar you need a sturdy bottom pot two ounces of water about a teaspoon of lemon juice then we stir that over heat now be careful you may burn yourself with water before probably on the stove but if you haven't had a sugar burning for a big surprise so it's much harder and you can as you push it off you also bring your hand that you push it off with so you want to stir away from you want to take your time you don't want it too high heat otherwise the sugar crystals burn on the side of the pot so don't stir it so much and we'll put this on medium heat until this caramelizes it'll take us a few minutes and then we'll come back all right now it achieved a light caramel color you want to put it right on ice that cools it down immediately let that cool down and stir a little bit it's going to harden on the bottom of the pan that's fine because we're going to add some heated heavy cream you pour in the heavy cream cold it kind of causes a little implosion you can burn yourself so we cool this down on ice back on the heat then we add three quarters of a cup of heavy cream whipping cream then we'll let that boil for about a minute and then it's just a matter of letting that cool down so that you can serve it with your favorite fruit so we'll turn up the heat a little more and it's like about high so let's get a little lower about medium and that'll start releasing this sugar is it this one be very careful you don't want to get stuck and splash yourself so heat up again let's see it's stuck on the bottom there's your nice caramel nice caramel nice caramel sauce and this caramel sauce which in fact it is is used as a sauce for bread pudding or for a fruit dip so it has lots of nice uses for it so you can see it's getting back to heat now and the purpose of that putting on ice once it reaches a light amber color is to stop the cooking process and make sure you heat the heavy cream then add that as you saw so that there's no explosion or you know it tends to splash up it'll burn yourself so now it comes the boil for one minute that way the cream is fully incorporated into the sugar water and lemon juice and now it's ready to be very careful it's very hot i wouldn't have too many children or pets around if you're making this so now it'll be sauce-like and dip like refrigerate that and use it until it's all used up so there you have it your beautiful caramel dip for fruit well thanks for joining us today at learn2cook.com be sure to comment and to subscribe also visit us on facebook and twitter have a great day and thank you

title: How to Make Caramel Apples
original_title: How to make Caramel Candy Apples | Homemade Fall Thanksgiving treat  Kravings
content: hi everyone welcome back to craving food adventures I'm Karin Ahmed fall is finally here and you know what that means we have a bounty of Delicious apples in Ontario today I decided to make these delicious candy apples at coated it in caramel and chocolate but you can customize it any way you like make sure you follow me on my channel as well as craving food adventures calm I'm going to be making a lot of apple recipes this fall before I go any further with this recipe do make sure you subscribe to my channel and ring the bell that youtube spell icon that will notify you every time I upload a new video now let's get making these Delicious apples to prep we need to remove any wax that may be present on the surface of the Apple I have a pot of boiling water here and I'm going to add 4 tablespoons of apple cider vinegar you can use any vinegar that you like you can also use any kind of apples that you like to balance the sweet of the caramel and chocolate I've chosen that tart granny smith apples I've also chosen to use snacking apples which are much smaller than a regular sized apple I'm going to immerse the apple in the water just for a few seconds and once that's done I'm going to remove it and place it on a towel [Music] once all of these are done I'm going to wipe each one dry using a kitchen towel [Music] for best results I'm going to refrigerate the apples before use if the Apple is cold it's going to set the caramel quickly it's also going to help to dry out the apples once all of my apples are chilled I'm going to remove them and take the stems off if the stem is nice and long one tug and it should come right out I like to make these apples in smaller batches about eight at a time if you find that you're struggling with a shorter stem just leave it on candy apple sticks are available in most stores I bought these bamboo lollipop sticks for another recipe and they work really well they're sharp on one end and they are so easy to pierce through the core of the Apple I like to go about 3/4 through the fruit so it's nice and secure if all you can find are the flat candy sticks you might want to stab the Apple first with a knife just to help the steak goal right through I have about 2 cups of walnuts here and I'm just going to crush them in my mortar and pestle you can use any other nuts of your choice pecans peanuts and almonds they all work well I also picked up a bunch of other sprinkles and candies from the bulk food store I have some pumpkins fall leaves and some Reese's you can use whatever you like and how much ever you like these are totally customizable the hardest part of this recipe is taking off the candy wrapper on these caramels I have a pound of caramel candies here and I'm going to add two tablespoons of milk [Music] after a minute give the stir you can see that the candy has started to melt but it's not quite as smooth yet I'm just going to put this back in the microwave for another minute use a bowl much larger than the quantity off the caramels as it does bubble and rice and as soon as you see it throught again I'm going to turn off the power this is now perfect but you're going to have to work fast as the caramel starts to thicken and Harden as it cools I'm going to be using a silicone mat as my base and I'm going to swirl the apples in the caramel and then quickly dip them in the walnut crumbs I just want to note if you want a caramel look but not necessarily dealing with the caramel you can also use butterscotch chips they are a bit more opaque than caramel but they will work just as well to make room I'm just going to move these onto a parchment paper line dish you want to make sure that you're never setting these directly on a plate as it will stick to the plate if using other candies or sprinkles just stick them on to the caramel or dip them in as soon as possible [Music] although the caramel sets pretty quickly it's still a bit tacky so you are going to need to stick this back in your fridge for an hour once it's set I'm going to add a layer of chocolate I'm using about 8 ounces of melted chocolate I'm just going to drizzle the chocolate and have some fun with it for the walnut apples I'm going to add more walnut crumbs on top of the chocolate drizzle [Music] if using candies or sprinkles do the same the chocolate takes longer to set than the caramel so you have a bit more time to decorate you can use any candies or chocolate that you fancy look how gorgeous these are you can serve these to your guests as is or wrap them up for the perfect take-home gift thank you so much for joining me in curving Santa ventures I hope you enjoyed this delicious recipe for candy coated apples as you can see it's super super easy to make and your friends and family will love to receive one of these make sure you subscribe to my channel guys and do share my channel and my videos with your family and friends and make sure to ring that Bell so you're notified every time I to do is comment on any video with the hashtag cravings and you will be entered automatically for your chance to win all of the details are in the description and be sure to follow me on cravings food adventures calm but also follow me behind the scenes on all of my social channels I'm on Facebook Instagram Pinterest Twitter and even snapchat till I see you next time do take care [Music]

content: last week on working class foodies we showed you how to make our family's traditional fail-proof apple cake a bunch of you sent in photos of your own cakes here's Louise is beautifully sugared square cake mdf smashes mouth-watering bundt cake Justin and Marissa teased us with a photo of their batter ready to go in the pan and clever kitty topped her cake with a maple glaze if you've got a recipe photo or video to share with us post a link in the comments are uploaded to hungry nation TV / submit so we had a lot of pumpkin seeds left over from all the jack-o'-lanterns we made and after the first few batches of roasted pumpkin seeds kind of got tired of them and then we tasted rocked her as a seasonal pumpkin seed brittle and it was so good the pumpkin seeds were gave a really nice toasty flavor and also a really good crunch to the brittle and even though I'd never made candy before I figured halloweens right around the corner you know what better time to try for the first time this week on working class foodies we found a recipe for pumpkin seed brittle by Dan barber the chef/owner of blue hill and blue hill stone barns in the new york times they looked easy and delicious so I need a couple three quarters of sugar three quarter cup water you three so I'm just going to stir it until it comes to a boil and then it's got to go to 264 degrees by get dress so it's at 264 so I'm gonna pull it off add in the salt and pumpkin seeds back it's really thick bill a stirring for thick porridge remove from heat so we add a butter in the vanilla and stir to incorporate so let me add the baking soda thank you out the smoke I might address gross for a thinner brutal stretch it while it's still hot with gloved hands the brittle was delicious enough on its own but Halloween is all about indulgence so we decided to coat our brittle and chocolate just like dr. Reza alternate between microwaving the chocolate for three seconds at a time and stirring it until chocolate is an 88 degrees Fahrenheit or 31 degrees Celsius or two degrees left for milk or white chocolate stir the chocolate until the temperature has dropped to 81 degrees Fahrenheit or 27 degrees Celsius and then add in the remaining four ounces of chocolate fold the tempered and non tempered chocolate together until they're uniformly melted if the chocolate dips below 81 degrees Fahrenheit you can use a hairdryer to bring the temperature back up check out Jacques terrorizes instructional video on tempering chocolate for more cool tips and advice once the chocolate is all melted together it's time to coat the brittle this is what it looks like when you temperature honest we let the brutal cool overnight and the next morning we packed it into bags to give to friends on Halloween stay tuned after the break we'll take a stab at some grown-up candy apples but not everything goes according to plan we'll from huntington new york i have a meta macaroni cheese I didn't like campbell's soup on macaroni goes in macaroni and cheese met nuclear cheese that comes with the craft box in heaven it's your macaroni cheese with every meal while we were kind of in the throes of our candy making craze in the second to last issue of Gourmet magazine had a recipe for sort of grown up candy apples made with red wine in the caramel it sounded kind of interesting let's make those to need eight small apples so I'm putting these chopsticks into the apples for holders I could use popsicle sticks or anything too but since we have takeout Chinese they have all these leftover chopsticks one and a half cups of red wines it's like a black first wine I've ever had oil the wine over medium heat until it's reduced to half a cup and then remove it from the heat then pour together two cups of sugar and half a cup of water in a heavy saucepan don't tell your dentist you're eating this stir the sugar and water together over medium heat when the caramel starts to boil swirl the pan occasionally is that the caramel color is evenly when it's a dark amber color add the wine and swirl the pan stir on six tablespoons of heavy cream and then simmer to 238 degrees Fahrenheit are 114 degrees Celsius then remove it from the heat and let it cool to 200 degrees Fahrenheit or 93 degrees Celsius dip the apples in the caramel swirl them so the caramel coach the apples evenly and hold them upside down for about 15 seconds to help the caramel set put the apples on greased wax paper or a greased Silpat until the caramel firms up I don't really know what happened but somehow these candy apples the caramel didn't stick and it melted off no good so I don't know what we did wrong if anybody else has tried this recipe please let us know help us I hope yeah tell us what we did wrong the failure of the candy apples was especially disheartening after the brittle came out so well and the great thing about the brittle is you could use any nut or seed or even dried fruit and be really delicious so the cost breakdown for the brittle was we use about a dollar fifty worth of corn syrup for pound of chocolate it was twelve dollars for a four pound pumpkin and its seeds it was a dollar sixty and then the sugar butter salt vanilla and baking soda was all Patrick so altogether that's fifteen dollars and ten cents and we made about ten bags so that's about a buck fifty back so the cost breakdown for the candy apples came to we used about two dollars worth of red wines who spent two dollars title: How to Make Caramel Apples
original_title: How to Make Fruit & Nut Caramels | Candy Making
content: so today I'm making fruit and nut caramel which are amazingly easy I'm starting with that a cup of sugar right into my pot a cup of heavy cream it's very low-fat recipe 1/2 a cup of corn syrup right into my pot and about three tablespoons of butter what that butter is going to do is really add richness to our caramels and they softened butter all I'm going to do is bring this to a boil on the stove it and keep cooking into becomes a nice golden brown so my caramel is ready to go it's very light in color but that is what we're looking for we're looking for something it's a little lighter than your traditional caramel think of it as like a nice tan color okay if we go too hard the problem is that when you go to cut your caramels they're gonna be so firm you're not gonna be able to get nice chewy bits of caramel you're gonna have like really hard pieces of caramel so all I'm gonna do is add in my final ingredient which is a nice mix of fruit and nuts you use any kind that you like this is a nice mix of cranberries I have some pumpkin seeds and pistachios some almonds just kind of throw them in there it's about a cup of fruit and nuts and I'm just gonna save some of them just sprinkle over the top so we'll give it a really nice finishing look last thing is a little bit of sea salt I'm using a kosher salt be generous you'll find that that'll really bring out the flavor of everything that's in there especially the caramel so again it's gonna look super light remember that just gonna keep cooking a little bit as it cools down so don't be afraid of the color but I'm gonna go right into I have a six-inch pan here or if you have a nice loaf pan that would be great I'm just gonna fill that up and then just finish it off by sprinkling the rest of my fruit nuts right over the top I really like mine chock-full it's like fruit and nuts I feel like that's the best part and this is a perfect candy to kind of wrap up and keep in your purse it's a good pick-me-up it's actually not so bad for you because you're only having a little bit of caramel and lots of really good fruit and nuts in there and if you like a little extra sea salt over the top and that is it so I'm gonna chill this you can pop it into the freezer or you can leave it at room temperature overnight just wrap it up with a nice piece of plastic wrap and then it's going to be ready to cut so I have my caramels nice and cool and ready to cut you can see they're really firm so I'm going to take my knife and I'm just gonna go ahead and give it a good slice I'm gonna make little rectangles but you could do any shape that you like you do little squares you do little triangles but all I'm going to do is do nice slices in one direction mine are about half an inch wide and then I'm just going to turn it around trim off the edge and do small slices in the other direction then you have these beautiful little candies delicious and that's how you make fruit and nut caramel

title: How to Make Caramel Apples
original_title: How to Make Salted Caramel Candies
content: I love salty sweet desserts and candies like these salted caramels but I'll be honest they can be a little bit tricky to make but I promise that you can make them with a little bit of help from me a couple tricks and a handy-dandy candy thermometer you too can make salted caramels and have them in your hand and now tonight in a medium saucepan combine a cup and a half of sugar a quarter cup each of corn syrup and water stir just to combine and then stop let it come to a boil and add a heaping teaspoon of salt when it begins to turn golden brown around the edges swirl the pan ever so gently so it caramelizes evilly but don't put that spoon back in when it becomes a deep caramelized color whisk in the butter and heavy cream but be careful it's going to bubble up like crazy let it continue cooking until the color deepens a few shades darker and it reaches 250 degrees this is called the firm ball stage and it's going to ensure these are the right chewy texture pour it into an eight-by-eight pan oh hey that's been lined with parchment and coated with cooking spray top it with more flaky sea salt and then whack it a few times on the counter to get rid of any air bubbles cut a few rectangles out of wax paper and set them aside allow the mixture to cool several hours or overnight to totally solid remove it from the parchment cut into long strips and sprinkle with more sea salt then cut into whatever size pieces you want I like a two bite-sized wrap it in the wax paper twist the ends of seal there you have it salted caramels y'all so rich and buttery and caramel a pop from the sea salt just girls bar at the top it's a good thing that these make really good gifts because if I cut them all here it would be bad news I'm going to give the rest of these away if you choose to keep them all for yourself I'm not going to judge best I hope you make them i'll see you next time

title: How to Make Caramel Apples
